page.title: 18Language: dialect
page.content: The following are in common use: bad fettle (ill), biggin (house), bogle (ghost), brat (apron), canaptious (awkward), crack (chat), flough (exposed), girt (great), gyavelick (crowbar), havvermeal (oatmeal), heck (hay rack), hod on (wait), kenspeckle (garish), kessen (sheep on its back), kist (meal-chest), laiking (playing), liggy (fish), lish (agile), moudy (mole), neb (nose), powsowdy (mess), scrow (untidy), snek (latch), snekposset (snub), yet (gate). Most names of hamlets, farmsteady or fields contain some element derived from Old Norse. Eg: thwaite (clearing) in Branthwaite, rigg (ridge) in Greenrigg, bygg (barley) and garth (enclosure) in Biggards, hvelpr (whelp) and Haugr (hill) in Whelpo, beck & sike (both stream) in Ellerbeck & Black Sike, wath (ford) in Wath Brow
